pull_request.title: Support namespace-package that has some packages inside the repo and some outside
pull_request.body:
As discussed in https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/discussions/17286, I'm trying to support the use-case in which some of the packages of a namespace-package reside in the monorepo, while other are sourced elsewhere.

This draft change makes it so the ambiguity warning is not present anymore.
However:
1. I hope it is due to it being fixed and properly inferred, rather than the change only hiding the error.
2. I'm not sure how to replace `NAMESPACES` with an dynamic inference in `map_first_party_python_targets_to_modules` and `map_third_party_modules_to_addresses`.
3. I'm not sure about the naming of the new `enum`. Maybe change it to a `is_namespace_package` boolean or `ModuleProviderPackage` with `.NAMESPACE` and `.STANDARD`/`.REGULAR`?

issue.title: Warnings for un-inferred dependencies are not always consistant when using `pantsd`
issue.body:
**Bug description**
In [a reproduction example](https://github.com/TalAmuyal/pants-repro/tree/namespace_collision_example), I’m describing an issue I’m having.
For the issue to be reproduced consistently, I’m adding `--no-pantsd` to `pants package ::`.

**Pants version**
Tried with `2.14.0rc4` and `2.14.0rc5`.

**OS**
I encounter the bug on MacOS, didn't try on Linux.

**Additional info**
When discussing it on Slack, @benjyw clearified that what's happening is that since this is a warning (rather than an error) the result is still memoized in `pantsd`’s **memory**, so to reproduce it `pantsd` need to be avoided or restarted.
That’s **not** a persistent cache on disk, and thus it does not survives `pantsd` restarts and doesn't persist from one daemon-less run to another.

issue.title: Support `BUILD`.`module_mapping` for Python package inference in `pants.toml`
issue.body:
It would be easier and more intuitive to support organization-internal (first-party) non-standard package names, if the [internal Pants mapping](https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/0e6719ac88d20b500bf0294d2f810ccd2bcf8d7e/src/python/pants/backend/python/dependency_inference/default_module_mapping.py#L6) could be extended in the global configuration file (that is, the root `pants.toml`).

For example, given the following section in the root `pants.toml` file:
```toml
[python-infer]
module_mapping.add = {
  "company-python-utils" = ["db_utils", "string_utils"],
  "company-python-creds" = ["company_creds"],
}
```
The config parser will do an equivalent to the following (made up pseudo code):
```python
import itertools

from pants.backend.python.dependency_inference.default_module_mapping import DEFAULT_MODULE_MAPPING


def get_module_mapping(
    parsed_pants_toml: dict,
    parsed_build_file: dict,
) -> dict:
    """
    Apply `python-infer.module_mapping.add` and `BUILD.__defaults__.python_requirements.module_mapping` if configured.
    """
    additions = itertools.chain(
        parsed_pants_toml.get("python-infer", {}).get("module_mapping", {}).get("add", {}).items(),
        parsed_build_file.get("__defaults__", {}).get("python_requirements", {}).get("module_mapping", {}).items(),
    )

    result = DEFAULT_MODULE_MAPPING.copy()
    for pypi_name, import_names in additions:
        result[pypi_name] = tuple(import_names)

    return result
```

For a repository that has an extensive use of non-standard package names in multiple packages, this will be a simple, efficient, and elegant solution.

Assuming the team is onboard with this idea (or a variation of it), I'd like to offer to put up a PR with an implementation.
Note that in that case, that would be my first PR for Pants, so I'd appreciate a few pointers on how to adjust the example above (or the alternative) to the actual project.

My bad, I will clarify
There are 2 use-cases I see for this feature.

The first use-case is an organization-internal package which is in another repo.
For example, if it is owned by another division in the company and thus has its own (maybe mono) repo.

The second use-case is that there is a package on PyPi that is not yet in the [internal Pants mapping](https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/0e6719ac88d20b500bf0294d2f810ccd2bcf8d7e/src/python/pants/backend/python/dependency_inference/default_module_mapping.py#L6), so as a temp fix it can be added for that repo.

issue.title: Teach add to work with iterables
issue.body:
Hi, @elimintz, thanks for this project!
I used JustPy in a hackathon a couple of weeks ago and I enjoy it very much :)

I'd like to suggest that `add` will support arguments that are iterables.
I find it useful when generating things in a comprehension.

For example:

```python
jp.Table().add(
    jp.Tr().add(
        ...
    ),
    [
        jp.Div(...)
        for user in users
    ],
)
```

What do you think?

comment.body:
@WolfgangFahl , thanks for taking the time and investing in this project.
I'm fine with it either way.

pull_request.title: Support namespace-package that has some packages inside the repo and some outside
pull_request.body:
As discussed in https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/discussions/17286, I'm trying to support the use-case in which some of the packages of a namespace-package reside in the monorepo, while other are sourced elsewhere.

This draft change makes it so the ambiguity warning is not present anymore.
However:
1. I hope it is due to it being fixed and properly inferred, rather than the change only hiding the error.
2. I'm not sure how to replace `NAMESPACES` with an dynamic inference in `map_first_party_python_targets_to_modules` and `map_third_party_modules_to_addresses`.
3. I'm not sure about the naming of the new `enum`. Maybe change it to a `is_namespace_package` boolean or `ModuleProviderPackage` with `.NAMESPACE` and `.STANDARD`/`.REGULAR`?

issue.title: Warnings for un-inferred dependencies are not always consistant when using `pantsd`
issue.body:
**Bug description**
In [a reproduction example](https://github.com/TalAmuyal/pants-repro/tree/namespace_collision_example), I’m describing an issue I’m having.
For the issue to be reproduced consistently, I’m adding `--no-pantsd` to `pants package ::`.

**Pants version**
Tried with `2.14.0rc4` and `2.14.0rc5`.

**OS**
I encounter the bug on MacOS, didn't try on Linux.

**Additional info**
When discussing it on Slack, @benjyw clearified that what's happening is that since this is a warning (rather than an error) the result is still memoized in `pantsd`’s **memory**, so to reproduce it `pantsd` need to be avoided or restarted.
That’s **not** a persistent cache on disk, and thus it does not survives `pantsd` restarts and doesn't persist from one daemon-less run to another.

commits.message: Avoid the daemon rather than restarting Pants
Reproduction

issue.title: Support `BUILD`.`module_mapping` for Python package inference in `pants.toml`
issue.body:
It would be easier and more intuitive to support organization-internal (first-party) non-standard package names, if the [internal Pants mapping](https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/0e6719ac88d20b500bf0294d2f810ccd2bcf8d7e/src/python/pants/backend/python/dependency_inference/default_module_mapping.py#L6) could be extended in the global configuration file (that is, the root `pants.toml`).

For example, given the following section in the root `pants.toml` file:
```toml
[python-infer]
module_mapping.add = {
  "company-python-utils" = ["db_utils", "string_utils"],
  "company-python-creds" = ["company_creds"],
}
```
The config parser will do an equivalent to the following (made up pseudo code):
```python
import itertools

from pants.backend.python.dependency_inference.default_module_mapping import DEFAULT_MODULE_MAPPING


def get_module_mapping(
    parsed_pants_toml: dict,
    parsed_build_file: dict,
) -> dict:
    """
    Apply `python-infer.module_mapping.add` and `BUILD.__defaults__.python_requirements.module_mapping` if configured.
    """
    additions = itertools.chain(
        parsed_pants_toml.get("python-infer", {}).get("module_mapping", {}).get("add", {}).items(),
        parsed_build_file.get("__defaults__", {}).get("python_requirements", {}).get("module_mapping", {}).items(),
    )

    result = DEFAULT_MODULE_MAPPING.copy()
    for pypi_name, import_names in additions:
        result[pypi_name] = tuple(import_names)

    return result
```

For a repository that has an extensive use of non-standard package names in multiple packages, this will be a simple, efficient, and elegant solution.

Assuming the team is onboard with this idea (or a variation of it), I'd like to offer to put up a PR with an implementation.
Note that in that case, that would be my first PR for Pants, so I'd appreciate a few pointers on how to adjust the example above (or the alternative) to the actual project.

comment.body:
My bad, I will clarify
There are 2 use-cases I see for this feature.

The first use-case is an organization-internal package which is in another repo.
For example, if it is owned by another division in the company and thus has its own (maybe mono) repo.

The second use-case is that there is a package on PyPi that is not yet in the [internal Pants mapping](https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/0e6719ac88d20b500bf0294d2f810ccd2bcf8d7e/src/python/pants/backend/python/dependency_inference/default_module_mapping.py#L6), so as a temp fix it can be added for that repo.

issue.title: Teach add to work with iterables
issue.body:
Hi, @elimintz, thanks for this project!
I used JustPy in a hackathon a couple of weeks ago and I enjoy it very much :)

I'd like to suggest that `add` will support arguments that are iterables.
I find it useful when generating things in a comprehension.

For example:

```python
jp.Table().add(
    jp.Tr().add(
        ...
    ),
    [
        jp.Div(...)
        for user in users
    ],
)
```

What do you think?

comment.body:
@WolfgangFahl , thanks for taking the time and investing in this project.
I'm fine with it either way.

3. I'm not sure about the naming of the new `enum`. Maybe change it to a `is_namespace_package` boolean or `ModuleProviderPackage` with `.NAMESPACE` and `.STANDARD`/`.REGULAR`?

pull_request.body:
As discussed in https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/discussions/17286, I'm trying to support the use-case in which some of the packages of a namespace-package reside in the monorepo, while other are sourced elsewhere.

This draft change makes it so the ambiguity warning is not present anymore.
However:
1. I hope it is due to it being fixed and properly inferred, rather than the change only hiding the error.
2. I'm not sure how to replace `NAMESPACES` with an dynamic inference in `map_first_party_python_targets_to_modules` and `map_third_party_modules_to_addresses`.
3. I'm not sure about the naming of the new `enum`. Maybe change it to a `is_namespace_package` boolean or `ModuleProviderPackage` with `.NAMESPACE` and `.STANDARD`/`.REGULAR`?

issue.title: Warnings for un-inferred dependencies are not always consistant when using `pantsd`
issue.body:
**Bug description**
In [a reproduction example](https://github.com/TalAmuyal/pants-repro/tree/namespace_collision_example), I’m describing an issue I’m having.
For the issue to be reproduced consistently, I’m adding `--no-pantsd` to `pants package ::`.

**Pants version**
Tried with `2.14.0rc4` and `2.14.0rc5`.

**OS**
I encounter the bug on MacOS, didn't try on Linux.

**Additional info**
When discussing it on Slack, @benjyw clearified that what's happening is that since this is a warning (rather than an error) the result is still memoized in `pantsd`’s **memory**, so to reproduce it `pantsd` need to be avoided or restarted.
That’s **not** a persistent cache on disk, and thus it does not survives `pantsd` restarts and doesn't persist from one daemon-less run to another.

commits.message: Avoid the daemon rather than restarting Pants
Reproduction

issue.title: Support `BUILD`.`module_mapping` for Python package inference in `pants.toml`
issue.body:
It would be easier and more intuitive to support organization-internal (first-party) non-standard package names, if the [internal Pants mapping](https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/0e6719ac88d20b500bf0294d2f810ccd2bcf8d7e/src/python/pants/backend/python/dependency_inference/default_module_mapping.py#L6) could be extended in the global configuration file (that is, the root `pants.toml`).

For example, given the following section in the root `pants.toml` file:
```toml
[python-infer]
module_mapping.add = {
  "company-python-utils" = ["db_utils", "string_utils"],
  "company-python-creds" = ["company_creds"],
}
```
The config parser will do an equivalent to the following (made up pseudo code):
```python
import itertools

from pants.backend.python.dependency_inference.default_module_mapping import DEFAULT_MODULE_MAPPING


def get_module_mapping(
    parsed_pants_toml: dict,
    parsed_build_file: dict,
) -> dict:
    """
    Apply `python-infer.module_mapping.add` and `BUILD.__defaults__.python_requirements.module_mapping` if configured.
    """
    additions = itertools.chain(
        parsed_pants_toml.get("python-infer", {}).get("module_mapping", {}).get("add", {}).items(),
        parsed_build_file.get("__defaults__", {}).get("python_requirements", {}).get("module_mapping", {}).items(),
    )

    result = DEFAULT_MODULE_MAPPING.copy()
    for pypi_name, import_names in additions:
        result[pypi_name] = tuple(import_names)

    return result
```

For a repository that has an extensive use of non-standard package names in multiple packages, this will be a simple, efficient, and elegant solution.

Assuming the team is onboard with this idea (or a variation of it), I'd like to offer to put up a PR with an implementation.
Note that in that case, that would be my first PR for Pants, so I'd appreciate a few pointers on how to adjust the example above (or the alternative) to the actual project.

My bad, I will clarify
There are 2 use-cases I see for this feature.

The first use-case is an organization-internal package which is in another repo.
For example, if it is owned by another division in the company and thus has its own (maybe mono) repo.

The second use-case is that there is a package on PyPi that is not yet in the [internal Pants mapping](https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/blob/0e6719ac88d20b500bf0294d2f810ccd2bcf8d7e/src/python/pants/backend/python/dependency_inference/default_module_mapping.py#L6), so as a temp fix it can be added for that repo.

issue.title: Teach add to work with iterables
issue.body:
Hi, @elimintz, thanks for this project!
I used JustPy in a hackathon a couple of weeks ago and I enjoy it very much :)

I'd like to suggest that `add` will support arguments that are iterables.
I find it useful when generating things in a comprehension.

For example:

```python
jp.Table().add(
    jp.Tr().add(
        ...
    ),
    [
        jp.Div(...)
        for user in users
    ],
)
```

What do you think?

comment.body:
@WolfgangFahl , thanks for taking the time and investing in this project.
I'm fine with it either way.
